ALLEGATION: Youth A and Youth B were watching a movie on 1/29/22.
Youth B touched Youth A in the genitals under his underwear. The children
were under a blanket together. A safety plan was put into place.
INVESTIGATION:
Whaley Children’s Center is a open residential program serving males and females, age
range 5-17 who are permanent or temporary court wards.
On 2/16/22, I spoke to Administrator 1. Allegations and scheduling was discussed as
well as documentation needed for the investigation.
I reviewed the following documents throughout the course of the investigation:
 Face sheets
 Incident reports (14)
 Sexual Safety Plan
 Whaley’s Staff Shadow Workbook
 Team Meeting Agenda (2)
 Individual Supervision Form
 Child Supervision Policy
 Respite policy
Video observation was available.
All interviews were conducted face to face at the facility.
It is to be noted that Youth B is not a resident of this facility. The agency moved him
from license number CI250309991 and placed him into Mott’s Children Residence. This
placement was made on 1/28/22 and Youth B remained at the facility until 1/31/22.
I reviewed seven incident reports pertaining to Youth B.
10/24/20: Youth B had kissed staff’s hand and told her “I just love you”
11/6/20: Youth B grabbed staff’s hand and kissed it. He told staff “I love you” and then
hugged the staff.
11/6/20: (15 minutes after the previous incident report): Youth B rubbed his feet up
against a staff’s foot.
2/11/21 (2): (Incident 1) Youth B was in the shower naked, and another female peer
was in the shower as well with her clothes on. (Incident 2) Youth B had himself
barricaded in the bathroom and therapist was able to get in and observed a female
peers coat, shoes, and socks on the bathroom floor. A licensing investigation was
completed for this incident. Special Investigation Number:
2/13/22: Youth B attempted to go into another peer’s bedroom
2/14/22: Youth B was upset that Youth A was telling everyone that he (Youth B)
touched Youth A
3

2/13/22: Youth A reported he was “scared” due to Youth B “was touching my wiener and
wanted me to have sex with him”. Youth A reported that the staff watching them was
asleep.
2/14/22: Youth A reported to staff that Youth B touched his genitals under a blanket
while they were watching a movie. 3200 filed and initial safety plan in effect for youth to
not have any contact.
I reviewed the Sexual Safety Plan for Youth B. Youth B had an original safety plan on
12/22/20 and an updated one was completed on 2/16/22. The original and updated
safety plan discussed the past history of Youth B and documented precautions that staff
are to take. Some precautions pertinent to this investigation are:
 Staff must have visual contact with Youth B when interacting with peers at all
times
 Staff must ensure that Youth B respects the personal boundaries of others
including staff and peers
 Youth B must be seated next to a staff or in visual range of staff at all times
 Staff must ensure they are able to see Youth B’s hands at all times when he is
seated.
 Youth B will not be sitting within arms reach of any other youth and must sit in his
own seat including when sitting at a dinner table, watching tv, in vehicles, etc.
 Youth B will not be allowed to share any blankets with other youth and will not be
allowed access to blankets outside of his bedroom
Interviews:
I interviewed Youth C. Youth C reported he was watching the movie Godzilla with Youth
A and Youth B with Staff 1. Youth C reported that Youth B is normally in a different
facility but has been at their facility before. Youth C reported that Youth B came to their
facility because another youth was targeting him. Youth C reported that Youth A and
Youth B sat next to each other on the couch and shared a blanket. Youth C reported the
blanket was across their lap. Youth C reported that the lights were on during the movie.
Youth C reported he did not know whether Youth A and Youth B were touching each
other.
I interviewed Youth A. Youth A reported they were watching the movie, Shazam with
Youth B and Youth C, and Staff 1. Youth A reported that Youth B is not normally in their
unit. Youth A reported that Youth C got into a fight and so he was allowed to spend the
night at their unit. Youth A reported that Youth C was sitting on the corner with Staff 1
and Youth A was sitting with Youth B. Youth A reported the lights were turned off and
they had blankets out for the movie. Youth A reported that Youth B had his blanket out
and Youth A reported he put Youth B’s blanket on his lap. Youth A reported the blanket
was over both his lap and Youth B’s lap. Youth A reported that Staff 1 was sleeping.
Youth A reported he knew this because Youth A was snoring. Youth A reported that
Youth B touched his penis under his underwear. Youth A reported Youth B was
squeezing his penis as well. Youth A reported Youth B touched his (Youth A’s) butt
4

under his clothing as well. Youth A reported he did not say anything to Youth B or to
staff. Youth A reported he did not tell Youth B to stop touching him. Youth A reported
that Youth B has never touched him before in this manner. Youth A reported he has
only received hugs from Youth B. Youth A reported that Youth B asked him to come into
his (Youth B’s) room on 2/13/22.
I interviewed Youth B. Youth B reported he was watching the movie Shazam with Youth
A, Youth C, and Staff 1. Youth B reported that during the movie the lights were out and
they were allowed to have their blankets. Youth B reported he shared a blanket with
Youth A. Youth B reported that Youth A kept asking him (Youth B) to touch him and
Youth B reported he kept pushing Youth A away. Youth B reported that Youth A kept
saying, “I’m going to touch you if you don’t let me use your MPs player”. Youth B
reported that staff wasn’t asleep but he kept scrolling through his phone throughout the
movie. Youth B reported he did not touch Youth A.
I interviewed Staff 1. Staff 1 was hired on 12/6/21 and transferred to this unit on 1/30/22.
Staff 1 reported he was not initially in this unit during the beginning of his shift on
1/29/22 but was rotated into it. Staff 1 reported that Youth B was not a part of the unit
but came to the unit during his shift. Staff 1 reported that no one talked to him about the
precautions he needed to take with Youth B. Staff 1 reported when first hired, he had to
read through all the children’s files to become familiar with them. Staff 1 reported he
was not aware that other youth could not sit next to him. Staff 1 reported that no one
ever gave him a safety plan for Youth B. Staff1 reported that the children had blankets
but there is no policy on blankets. Staff 1 reported that both Youth A and Youth C had
blankets. Staff 1 reported that the lights were off until another staff came in and told him
he couldn’t have the lights off. Staff 1 reported he did use his phone to look up email
and did report that he might have closed his eyes but did not fall asleep. Staff 1 reported
that he was not interested in the movie, so he wasn’t paying attention. Staff 1 reported
he did have his hoodie on and so it may have looked like he was sleeping. Staff 1
reported that he was not paying attention to them as he should have been.
I reviewed the Children’s Supervision Policy:
…Staff must remain awake and alert at all times when on duty…staff cannot lie down,
be in a reclined position…immobile for more than 15 consecutive minutes…LIGHTING:
lights are to be kept on while in any environment…this includes while watching
television…Personal cell phones are not permitted on the floor and cannot be used by
staff in ratio during working hours…
I interviewed Administrator 2. Administrator 2 reported that half of the youth have safety
plans in their files. Administrator 2 reported that all staff are to read safety plans weekly
and sign a document stating they have done so. Administrator 2 reported the supervisor
would ensure that the staff are signing off on these. Administrator 2 reported even if
Youth B is in another facility, all staff have access to all youth’s files in both facilities.
Administrator 1 reported that after Staff 1 was hired he completed training and then had
5

one mandatory team meetings that he would have been in where he would have
discussed the children in the unit and any other needs or treatment interventions for the
children. Administrator 1 reported Staff 1 did attend. Administrator 1 reported that Staff
1 would have been well aware of the safety plans for Youth B and should have known
the policy on child supervision concerning blankets, lights, cell phones, and sleeping.
Administrator 2 provided the following documents:
 Acknowledgement Receipt for New Hire Paperwork
 Individual Supervision Form
 Team Meeting Agenda
 Staff Shadow Workbook
Staff 1 signed off on the Acknowledgement Receipt for New Hire Paperwork stating
he reviewed the Child Supervision Policy on 12/6/21.
I reviewed the Individual Supervision Form dated 1/4/22. This form was a welcome
form for Staff 1 to the unit. It was to inform Staff 1 of the duties of his job.
Under the subheading “Tasks to be Completed”, it was Staff 1’s task to “read and
sign off on the Population Booklet weekly…and to attend Mandatory Monthly Team
Meetings.
I reviewed the Team Meeting Agenda dated 2/11/22. This would have been the first
team meeting that Staff 1 went to in his new unit. Team Meeting Agenda discussed
consistency in routines and structure no matter what staff is supervising youth.
I reviewed the Staff Shadow Workbook that Staff 1 signed on 12/17/21. Staff 1
completed this during his initial training at the facility. On page 2 of the handbook,
question 2 asks: “Name a child residing on a unit/group home on which you shadowed
that has a sexual safety plan.” Staff 1 named Youth B. Question 3 asks: “List 3 things
mentioned within the sexual safety plan pertaining to that specific child:” Staff 3 reported
Youth B’s history of perpetuating sexual abuse on family members.
I asked to review the weekly sign off sheets pertaining to staff reviewing the weekly
Population Booklets, which contain the Sexual Safety Plan. This was destroyed by one
of the youth so these were not available for review.
I observed the video footage for the incident. The lights were off during the movie. Staff
1 and Youth C were on one side of the couch and Youth A and Youth B were right next
to each other sharing a blanket. Youth A was on the left of Youth B. Youth A had his
hands under the blanket and there was movement on and near Youth B’s lap area
under the blanket. At one point Youth A pushed back the blanket covering them up and
placed his head over top Youth B’s genital area.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both the
following:
(a) ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 was given the Child Supervision Policy and A Sexual
Safety Plan that specifically laid out staff interventions that were
to be used with Youth B. Although he had these tools, he was
unable to perform the duties assigned to him.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS Staff 1 was provided with the Sexual Safety Plan for Youth B,
which expressed:
 Staff must have visual contact with Youth B when
interacting with peers at all times
 Staff must ensure that Youth B respects the personal
boundaries of others including staff and peers
 Youth B must be seated next to a staff or in visual range
of staff at all times
 Staff must ensure they are able to see Youth B’s hands
at all times when he is seated.
 Youth B will not be sitting within arms reach of any other
youth and must sit in his own seat including when sitting
at a dinner table, watching tv, in vehicles, etc.
 Youth B will not be allowed to share any blankets with
other youth and will not be allowed access to blankets
outside of his bedroom
Staff 1 signed off that he had read the Child Supervision Policy.
Although Staff 1 had knowledge of Youth B’s Sexual Safety Plan
and the supervision policy he failed to perform his duty of
providing for the continual supervision and protection of the
youth.
7

CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS: Youth B is not placed at Mott’s Children
Residence, license number CI250201313. Youth B was removed from
his legal placement at license number CI250309991 and placed in
Mott’s Children Residence by the agency. The agency called this
“respite”.
INVESTIGATION:
Youth A reported that Youth B is not normally in their unit. Youth A reported that Youth
C got into a fight and so he was allowed to spend the night at their unit. Youth A
reported that Youth B asked him to come into his (Youth B’s) room on 2/13/22.
Youth B reported that he has stayed at this facility before and specifically during the
movie Shazam, he stayed the weekend. Youth B reported that Youth A has been over
at his placement and made allegation that he (Youth B) had asked him (Youth A) to
come into his room.
Youth C reported that Youth B is normally in a different facility but has been at their
facility before. Youth C reported that Youth B came to their facility because another
youth was targeting him.
Administrator 1 reported Youth B is normally at license number CI250309991 but due to
his behaviors he was placed into Mott’s Children Residence for “respite”.
Administrator 3 reported that Youth B was placed into Mott’s Children Residence on
1/28/22 and he stayed at the facility until 1/31/22. Administrator 3 reported they have
been moving children back and forth, between license for at least 5 years. Administrator
3 reported they even have a Respite Policy. Administrator 3 reported the DHS 3600
does not specify Youth B’s placement as Mott’s Children Residence.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's
case record:
(f) Documentation of legal right to provide care.
8

ANALYSIS: The agency did not have the legal right to provide care to Youth
B. They referred to Youth B moving from one agency to the
other as “respite”. “Respite”, as the agency describes it, is when
a child moves from one of their licensed facilities to another for
either:
 Safety reasons (youth is a target or is targeting other
peers)
 Lack of staffing
 Maltreatment in Care investigations (safety planning)
The agency was under the impression that they could move
children between licenses as long as the youth’s worker
approved this move. The agency administration reported this
change in placement occurs fluidly.
Youth B should not have been placed into the facility because
his legal placement is at license number CI250309991.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
The recommendation is to continue the current license status.
